description: From Middle English spectacle, from French spectacle, from Latin spectāculum (“a show, spectacle”), from spectō (“to see, behold”), frequentative of speciō (“to see”). See species.

entries.meaning: An exciting or extraordinary scene, exhibition, performance etc.
examples: The horse race was a thrilling spectacle.

entries.meaning: An embarrassing or unedifying scene or situation.
examples: He made a spectacle out of himself.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) An optical instrument consisting of two lenses set in a light frame, worn to assist sight, or to protect the eyes from bright light.
(rail transport) A frame with different coloured lenses on a semaphore signal through which light from a lamp shines at night, often a part of the signal arm.
